body:
> Adding new functionality to the standard library is a high bar. Generally we only do it for functions needed by a web server or by lots of programs.

Ok, good to know. Thanks for the insight. :-)

> A go-gettable package is just as usable.

Agreed, it is as useable. Though not as practically applicable for the enterprise. I first need to find the third party functionality, lock into the proper version, and then trust them explicitly.

> In particular, as far as I know, the C and C++ standard libraries do not have these functions.

For C++ I would reference this:
http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/next_permutation/
http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/prev_permutation/

And ruby:
http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.2.0/Array.html#method-i-combination

And as noted above, for python:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html.
